awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Microbiology at the University of Iowa
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Iowa, located in Iowa City, IA, will support the training of 8 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019-2021.  The scientific focus of the research program is microbiology.  Each student will conduct an independent laboratory research project under the guidance of a faculty and a graduate student co-mentor from the Department of Microbiology & Immunology. Lectures, workshops and social activities will promote professional development, familiarize students with graduate school and career options, and provide training in responsible conduct of research. Students will present their findings at a university-wide symposium and at regional and national meetings. The program is open to undergraduates who are interested in scientific research and are U.S. citizens or permanent residents. Recruitment will use both traditional mailings and various forms of electronic outreach. Special emphasis will be given to recruitment of students from demographic groups that are underrepresented in the sciences and/or students from small colleges (including community colleges) where opportunities for research are lacking. Students will be selected by the program directors based on academic record, letters of recommendation and potential for outstanding future careers in the biological sciences. Post-program mentoring will promote retention of students in the sciences, while tracking will assess the lasting influences of the research experience.

It is anticipated that a total of 24 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.medicine.uiowa.edu/microbiology/summer/ , or by contacting the PI (Dr. David Weiss at david-weiss@uiowa.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Linda McCarter at linda-mccarter@uiowa.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU in Microbiology at The University of Iowa supported 8 undergraduates from across the nation for ten-week research experiences during the summers of 2019, 2021, and 2022, for a total of 24 participants.  The goals of the program were to encourage students to pursue a career in basic science, to provide those students with the skills to succeed in that path, and to contribute to a diverse and well-educated STEM workforce.  To achieve these ends, students were placed in research labs, where they carried out independent projects under the supervision of faculty mentors.  Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows generally served as co-mentors.  Student participants were engaged not only in the daily tasks of conducting experiments, but also in the process of formulating hypotheses, designing experiments and interpreting the results.  To foster communication skills, participants were required to present their projects in the form of a short talk, a short written report and, at the end of the summer, a poster session.  Twice a week all participants gathered with the REU Co-Directors to engage in seminars and workshops.  The subject matter varied from week to week, but included research presentations by Department faculty, and workshops on career opportunities and the graduate school admissions process. Instruction in Responsible Conduct of Research was provided online. Social functions brought together students, their mentors and additional members of the department in settings that fostered interactions outside the walls of the laboratory.

In 2022 an ROA supplement supported a faculty member from a small college in rural Iowa, allowing this person to develop a research project and new teaching methods that she implemented upon return to her home institution. In 2022-23 a REPS supplement supported a post bac who is now a PhD candidate in virology at another university.

Intellectual merit: We are particularly proud of the contributions our REU participants have made towards pushing back the frontiers of knowledge.  Despite the constraint of only having 10 weeks to work in the lab, 8 of the students made enough progress that they were able to present their findings at national or regional scientific meetings, and 2 students won awards for their poster presentations at ABRCMS.

Broader impacts: Of the 24 undergraduate participants, 12 entered PhD programs, 4 entered post bac programs, 2 entered Medical School, and the remaining 6 did various things. Surveys at the end of each summer revealed nearly 100% of the participants reported good to great gains in a variety of important skills, such as their ability to analyze data, solve problems, work in the lab independently, and present their research to others.  Over 80% reported that participation in the REU program increased the likelihood they would pursue graduate school.  About 90% of the participants were from small colleges, and nearly all of the participants, including those from larger institutions, reported the REU was their first real research experience.  In keeping with the goal of developing a diverse STEM workforce, 16 of the 24 participants were female, 1 was non-binary, and 13 were underrepresented minorities.

Overall, our data indicate the REU in Microbiology at The University of Iowa achieved its goals during the 2019-2024 funding period.
